children.name: letter
children.definition: /ˈletəʳ/  a written or printed message that is usually put in an envelope and sent by mail:
examples: ▪ In a letter dated May 10th, the US government protested about the use of force in the republics.
letter from somebody
▪ I got a letter from Anna today.
letter to somebody
▪ Hamlin wrote a letter to the council, complaining about the incident.
write somebody a letter
▪ Write me a letter and tell me all your news!
get/receive a letter
▪ David, who won first prize in the lottery, has received more than 100 letters from charities asking for money.
letternoun[ C ]MESSAGEthư; thư từ; thư tín
a written message from one person to another, usually put in an envelope and sent by the post
_Igota letterfromthe bank this morning.
love letternoun[ C ]
a letter that you write to someone that you are having a romantic relationship with
open letternoun[ C ]thư ngỏ
a letter intended to be read by a lot of people, not just the person it is written to
_An open letter to the prime minister, signed by several MPs, appeared in today's papers.
covering letter/ notenoun[ C ] (UScover letter/note)
a letter or note which contains information about the thing it is sent with
_Please send a covering letter with your application form.

children.name: note
children.definition: /nəʊt/  a shortinformalletter written from one person to another:
examples: ▪ Just a quick note to say Helen had a baby boy yesterday -- 8lbs 6oz.
leave (somebody) a note
▪ I forgot to leave them a note to tell them we won’t be home by dinnertime.
suicide note
a note written just before someone kills themselves
▪ Police are puzzled about the man’s death. There was no sign of a struggle and no suicide note.
notenounWRITINGlời ghi, lời ghi chép
[ C ] a short piece of writing
_He left a note to say he would be home late.
_There's a note pinned to the door saying when the shop will open again.

children.name: memo
children.definition: /ˈmeməʊ/  ashortletterwritten from one person to another within a company or organization:
examples: ▪ Mr. Fitchel said he made the suggestion in a memo to his superiors.

children.name: send (out) a memo
examples: ▪ The Managing Director sent out a memo to all employees saying there would be a meeting at 10 o'clock.

children.name: correspondence
children.definition: /ˌkɒrɪˈspɒndəns, ˌkɒrəˈspɒndənsǁˌkɔːrˈspɑːn-, ˌkɑː-/  letters or e-mails that people write to each other regularly or over a long period of time:
examples: ▪ Your fax should include copies of any correspondence you have received from our office.
correspondence with
▪ The biography is based on Marx’s correspondence with Engels over 40 years.
correspondencenounWRITINGthư từ
[ U ] letters, especially official or business letters
_Any further correspondenceshould be sent to my new address.

children.name: e-mail/email
children.definition: /ˈiː meɪl/  an electronic message sent using the Internet:
examples: ▪ I came back from vacation to find 130 e-mails waiting for me.
send somebody (an) e-mail
▪ Several people sent us e-mail asking for help with the software.
get an e-mail
▪ I got an e-mail from Emma the other day.
by email
▪ The reports are sent out weekly by email.
e-mail address
the letters or numbers that people use to send you e-mail
▪ The e-mail address for the dictionaries department is dict.edit@pearsoned-ema.com.
e-mail/email [transitive verb] to send a message to someone using e-mail:
e-mail somebody
▪ I’ll e-mail you when I get to Boston.

children.name: Dear Sir/Sirs/Sir or Madam
children.definition: /ˌdɪəʳ ˈsɜːʳ, ˈsɜːʳz, ˌsɜːr ɔːʳ ˈmædəm/ use this in formal letters when you do not know the person’s name:
examples: ▪ Dear Sir or Madam, I am writing to ask for your help....

children.name: Dear Mr Wiggins/Ms Harper
children.definition: /ˌdɪəʳ mɪstəʳ ˈwɪgɪnz, mɪz ˈhɑːʳpəʳ/ use this in formal letters:
examples: ▪ Dear Mr Bartholomew, Thank you for your quick response.

children.name: Dear Jim/Sarah etc
children.definition: /ˌdɪəʳ ˈdʒɪm/ use this when you know the person well enough to use his or her first name:
examples: ▪ Dear Jackie, How are you?

children.name: Hi /Hey
children.definition: especially American /haɪ, heɪ/ use this in e-mails and letters to friends:
examples: ▪ Hi, how’s it going?
▪ Hey Jenny - good to hear from you again.

children.name: Yours faithfully
children.definition: /ˌjɔːʳz ˈfeɪθfəli/ British use this at the end of formal letters, which began with ‘Dear Sir’, ‘Dear Madam’ etc:
examples: ▪ Yours faithfully, Adam Browning

children.name: Yours sincerely
children.definition: /ˌjɔːʳz sɪnˈsɪəʳli/ British use this at the end of formal letters which begin with ‘Dear Mr ...’, ‘Dear Ms ...’ etc:
examples: ▪ Yours sincerely, Mary Whitford

children.name: Yours truly,/Sincerely,/Yours sincerely
children.definition: ,/ˌjɔːʳz ˈtruːli, sɪnˈsɪəʳli/ American use this at the end of formal letters:
examples: ▪ Yours truly, Donna Deavers

children.name: love (from)
children.definition: /ˈlʌv (frəm)/ use this at the end of letter to members of your family, close friends etc:
examples: ▪ I’ll give you a call soon. Love, Brad

children.name: All the best/Best wishes/With best wishes
children.definition: /ˌɔːl ðə ˈbest, ˌbest ˈwɪʃz, wɪð ˌbest ˈwɪʃz/ use this especially in letters or e-mails to friends and family:
examples: ▪ All the best, Dad

children.name: take care
children.definition: /ˌteɪk ˈkeəʳ/ use this at the end of letters to friends, to show that you will be thinking about them:
examples: ▪ Take care, Martin and Sophie

children.name: xxx
children.definition: also xoxo American use this at the end of letters and notes to people you love. The X’s represent kisses and the O’s represent hugs:
examples: ▪ xxx Moira

children.name: regards
children.definition: /rɪˈgɑːʳdz/ use this especially in letters or e-mails to people you know or work with, especially people who are not family or close friends:
examples: ▪ Regards, Jonathan Pryor

children.name: PS
children.definition: British /P.S. American /ˌpiː ˈes/ use this when you want to add something after the end of a letter:
examples: ▪ PS I love you.
▪ PS Send my regards to Pauline.

children.name: card
children.definition: nounGREETINGSthiếp
examples: [ C ] a rectangular piece of stiff paper, folded in half, with a picture on the front and often a messageprinted inside, sent on a special occasion
_anniversary/get-well cards
_It's Steve's birthday on Thursday -I mustsendhim a card.
Christmas cardnoun[ C ]thiệp mừng Nô-en
a decorated card that you send to someone atChristmas
valentinenoun[ C ]
(alsovalentine card) a decorative card which you send, usually without
your name on it, on 14 February (Valentine's Day) to someone you love
_Did you get any valentines?
_Most of the valentine cards either had hearts on them or were very rude.
greetings cardnoun[ C ]UK
(USgreeting card)thiệp chúc mừng (ngày sinh, ngày cưới, ngày lễ...)
a piece of thick paper folded in half with a picture on the outside and a message inside, which you write in and send or give to someone,for example atChristmasor on theirbirthday

children.name: envelope
children.definition: nounphong bì
examples: a flat, usually square or rectangular, paper container for a letter

children.name: postcard
children.definition: nounbưu thiếp
examples: a card, often with a photograph or picture on one side, which can be sent without an envelope

children.name: enclosed
children.definition: adjectiveSENT

children.name: sent to someone in an envelope with a letter
examples: _The enclosed card is for Julia.
_formalPlease find enclosed a cheque in settlement of your invoice.
